conclusion: Determine which light will first undergo total internal reflection by considering the critical angle.
Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a medium with a higher refractive index to a lower one.
The critical angle is given by sin(theta_c) = n2/n1, where n1 is the refractive index of the glass and n2 is the refractive index of the air.
Different monochromatic lights have different refractive indices in the glass.
The critical angle for light a is sin(theta_c,a) = 1/n_a.
The critical angle for light b is sin(theta_c,b) = 1/n_b.
If n_a > n_b, then theta_c,a < theta_c,b, meaning light a has a smaller critical angle.
As the angle of incidence increases, light a will reach its critical angle first and undergo total internal reflection before light b.
The statement that light b will first undergo total internal reflection is incorrect.
